prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Management of transferred cases—The Manual for Complex Litigation

para.paratext: The Manual's development parallels that of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation.[1] Both were born out of the flood of civil litigation in the federal courts in the 1960s following the criminal price-fixing indictments of companies and executives in the electrical equipment industry in 1960. Judicial attention had been focused on massive, time-consuming litigation even before the 1,912 separate treble-damage actions were filed in 35 different United States District Courts following the electrical equipment criminal indictments.[2]

Chief Justice Earl Warren appointed a special panel of the United States Judicial Conference in 1955. That group, the Judicial Conference Group on Protracted Litigation, published its Handbook of Recommended Procedures for the Trial of Protracted Cases in 1960.[3] The handbook was adopted in March, 1960 and is the earliest precursor of the present Manual.[4]

Pretrial activities in the electrical equipment cases were governed by another committee of the United States Judicial Conference, the Electrical Equipment Coordinating Committee, a subcommittee of the conference's Committee on Pretrial Procedure.[5] The subcommittee issued its Outline of Suggested Procedures and Materials for Pre-Trial and Trial of Complex and Multiple Litigation in 1966.[6] The Outline was followed in 1968 by the Manual for Complex and Multidistrict Litigation.[7] The Manual was later renamed the Manual for Complex Litigation to reflect its broader applicability than simply to multidistrict cases.

The Panel has explicitly and strongly supported use of the Manual in management of cases in the transferee district.[8] It is clear that the Panel's reluctance to interfere in transferred cases once they have been transferred or otherwise attempt to control or dictate the handling of them prevents the Panel from requiring any particular Manual procedures. Nonetheless, the Panel's entire approach to management of multidistrict litigation is consistent with the procedures suggested in the Manual. In addition, the Panel has frequently cited the Manual as a source of guidance in the handling of cases by the transferee courts. For example, in one decision the Panel noted that the transferee court could enter an appropriate order to permit discovery taken in one action before transfer by the Panel to be used against additional parties after transfer.[9] The Panel has also repeatedly noted that the Manual generally requires discovery to take place in a local district where a witness or other evidence is located, thus blunting arguments that transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would not advance the interests of the statute.[10] The Manual itself continues to evolve, and an updated and expanded Fourth Edition was issued by the Federal Judicial Center in 2004, drawing on and superceding the Third Edition of 1995. An annotated version of the Manual for Complex Litigation is published by West, and includes Authors' analysis as well as case and secondary authority updates.[11]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
